title.value: Learning Conditional Policies for Crystal Design Using Offline Reinforcement Learning
title.justification: The title is explicitly provided at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Learning Conditional Policies for Crystal Design Using Offline Reinforcement Learning

extractions.description: This paper presents a method to design novel and stable crystalline materials conditioned on a desired band gap by using offline reinforcement learning with conservative Q-learning. The study formulates crystal design as a sequential decision-making problem and evaluates the generated materials using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The results are compared with baselines like random policy and behavioral cloning.

type.justification: The paper includes experimental evaluation of the proposed method using datasets and numerical comparisons with existing methods, which is typical of empirical studies.
type.quote: Our experiments show that conditioned policies achieve targeted crystal design and demonstrate the capability to perform crystal discovery evaluated with accurate and computationally expensive DFT calculations.

name.justification: The research focuses on the discovery and design of novel crystalline materials using AI and reinforcement learning techniques, which fits within the domain of Materials Discovery.
name.quote: This work aims to design novel and stable crystalline materials conditioned on a desired band gap.

name.justification: The study utilizes reinforcement learning techniques, specifically offline reinforcement learning using conservative Q-learning, to address the problem of crystal design.
name.quote: To alleviate the issue of time-consuming DFT calculations when integrated into the scientific discovery loop, we apply offline reinforcement learning using the conservative Q-learning (CQL) approach.

name.justification: The evaluation of the designed materials involves computational chemistry techniques, specifically density functional theory (DFT) calculations.
name.quote: The reward function penalizes high energies and large deviations from the desired band gap using values computed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations.

name.justification: The paper explicitly states that it uses conservative Q-learning (CQL) as its reinforcement learning approach.
name.quote: To alleviate the issue of time-consuming DFT calculations when integrated into the scientific discovery loop, we apply offline reinforcement learning using the conservative Q-learning (CQL) approach.

is_contributed.justification: CQL has been previously established as a robust approach in reinforcement learning and is not a new contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Offline RL enables for learning an optimal policy directly from trajectories, making it possible to utilize knowledge from existing crystal structures.

is_executed.justification: The paper implements CQL but does not specify the computational hardware like GPU or CPU explicitly for this model.
is_executed.quote: We apply offline reinforcement learning using the conservative Q-learning (CQL) approach, which is known to mitigate overestimation and out-of-distribution issues when agents are trained with static datasets in an offline manner.

is_compared.justification: CQL is compared to other models like random policy and behavioral cloning in the experimental section.
is_compared.quote: Our experiments show that conditioned policies achieve targeted crystal design and demonstrate the capability to perform crystal discovery evaluated with accurate and computationally expensive DFT calculations.

name.justification: The paper uses the Materials Project database as the source of high-quality nonmetallic crystal structures.
name.quote: We construct a state transition dataset from high-quality nonmetallic crystal structures present in the Materials Project database.
